I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Indonesia’s long-term decentralization policy objectives are to improve the delivery of 
basic services and infrastructure to local communities across the country. Since implementation 
of the ―big bang‖ decentralization reforms in 2001, the Government of Indonesia has entrusted 
local  governments  with  the  responsibility  of  delivering  most  basic  public  services,  and 
reassigned two-thirds of its civil servants and more than 16,000 service delivery facilities to the 
local governments. Central government transfers to local governments now account for a third 
of total central government expenditures.  
 
2.  Local  service  delivery  is  mostly  financed  with  government  grants,  with  growing 
contributions from local revenues and borrowings. The largest unconditional grant available to 
local governments is the general allocation fund (DAU), which accounts on average for 50% of 
total local governments revenues. The local governments’ share of revenues from extractive 
industries—through the revenue sharing fund—represents 17% of their revenues; an additional 
7% is accounted for by the infrastructure development grant (the specific allocation fund [DAK]). 
Total grants to local governments have more than doubled since 2005, from an estimated 
Rp150 trillion to around Rp350 trillion in 2010. In 2010 local revenue, from limited taxes and 
charges, represented approximately 16% of total local governments’ revenue. However, recent 
assignments  of  new  sources  of  revenue  to  local  governments  are  likely  to  increase  the 
importance of this building block of local governments’ financing. 
 
3.  The post-program partnership framework of the recently approved loan for the Second 
Local  Government  Finance  and  Governance  Reform  Subprogram  2  (LGFGR2-S2)1  for 
Indonesia calls for (i) further improvement in the equalization power of the system of inter-
governmental fiscal grants, (ii) continued implementation of the decentralization of the property 
transfer tax (BPHTB) and land and building tax (PBB) to local governments, and (iii) sustained 
capacity development of public financial management (PFM) for local government officers. To 
build on this reform momentum, the government has requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) for capacity development technical assistance (TA) to support implementation of policy 
objectives under the LGFGR2-S2 post-program partnership framework. ADB fielded the fact-
finding mission in July 2011 and reached detailed understanding with the government on the 
objectives and scope of the TA, the terms of reference for consultants, and the cost and 
implementation arrangements. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  After 10 years of decentralization, local governments have assumed a critical role in 
public service delivery, and the overall quality of and access to basic public services have 
improved. However, many challenges remain. Access to basic services remains uneven across 
the country. A large number of local governments do not have the means to meet their service 
mandates due to low revenue-generating capacity and inefficient distribution of fiscal transfers. 
In areas where central and local governments have shared responsibilities, there is a great deal 
of  overlap  and  confusion.  The  intergovernmental  coordination  institutions  remain

2 
 
underdeveloped and ineffective. As a consequence, local government lacks the incentive to 
implement prudent fiscal management, resulting in poor local government performance. 
 
5.  Lack of clarity in the legal framework. A comprehensive reform of the policy and 
regulatory  framework  for  the  system  of  intergovernmental  fiscal  relations  in  Indonesia  is 
underway. The review includes a revision of all the system’s main elements: (i) expenditure and 
revenue assignments, (ii) intergovernmental fiscal grants, and (iii) local government’s borrowing 
powers. The reforms include amendments to the main decentralization laws (i.e., Law 32 on 
regional autonomy and Law 33 on fiscal balance) and associated government regulations, and a 
reconsideration of the mechanisms for new local government formation. Despite this progress, 
more clarity is still needed on expenditure assignments, the institutional framework for policy 
coordination at the central government level, and the processing of applications for new regions. 
Progress is pending upon the approval of the new amended Law 32.  
 
6.  Lack  of  revenue  collection  capacity  by  local  governments.  Successful  fiscal 
decentralization requires the assignment of adequate sources of own-source revenues to local 
governments. Indonesia has recently taken critical steps in this direction. Gradual devolution of 
the PBB and the BPHTB started in January 2011 upon enactment of Law 34 on regional 
government revenues and charges. The government plans to fully devolve the BPHTB by the 
end of 2011 and expects to complete the devolution of the PBB by 2014. However, ongoing 
institutional strengthening of revenue collection agencies will be needed. Administering land and 
property  taxes  is  cumbersome,  involving  sometimes  complex  mapping  and  valuation  and 
collection techniques, which are increasingly managed by sophisticated computer applications. 
 
7.  Need for enhanced equalization, predictability, and transparency in the release of 
fiscal transfers and shared revenue. Despite progress, substantial flaws remain in the design 
and coordination of the different elements of the system of intergovernmental grants. The 
formula used for the allocation of the largest unconditional grant to local governments, the DAU, 
fails to properly estimate both the expenditure needs and fiscal capacity of local governments, 
and does not distinguish between type and size of local administrations. The DAK, the transfer 
devoted to cover capital expenditure needs of local governments, suffers from poor targeting at 
the sector and jurisdictional levels. Importantly, the different elements of the system of transfers 
are  not  properly  coordinated,  resulting  in  inefficiencies  in  resource  allocation  across  local 
governments.  Lastly,  none  of  the  major  grant  mechanisms  have  adequate  performance 
incentives incorporated in their design, thereby limiting their effectiveness. 
 
8.  Poor  financial  management  capacities  at  the  local  government  level.  The 
decentralization process has placed an enormous burden on regional government officials. The 
new intergovernmental arrangement inherited a large administrative and institutional burden, 
with a multitude of public agencies, a lack of professional civil servants, uncertified accountants, 
weak public management systems, and graft and corruption at the local level. The latest data 
(2008) from the State Ministry for Administrative Reforms reveals that 50% of the country's four 
million civil servants had insufficient qualifications. Adequate capacity development of local 
authorities  is  needed,  and  is  particularly  important  to  enhance  the  transparency  of  fiscal 
transfers and the procurement process, and improve the capacity of regional government PFM 
officers to handle property taxes.

3 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
9.  The TA will build capacity in the Ministry of Finance (MOF), Ministry of Home Affairs 
(MOHA), and the National Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS) for the effective design 
and implementation of fiscal decentralization policies that are in line with LGFGR2-S2. This will 
include: (i) building the capacity of (a) the MOF Directorate General of Fiscal Balance (DGFB), 
with  primary  focus  on  the  Directorate  for  Regional  Taxes  and  Charges,  and  (b)  regional 
government PFM officials, for the efficient devolution of property taxes; (ii) assisting BAPPENAS 
(where  the  primary  counterpart  is  the  Directorate  of  Regional  Autonomy)  to  enhance 
equalization, predictability, and transparency in the allocation and release of on grant facilities, 
such as DAK; and (iii) improving the capacity of the regional  government PFM officials by 
engaging selected regional universities to provide PFM training.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be to improve access to and coverage of basic public services to local 
communities across the country. The outcome will be enhanced management and coordination 
of fiscal decentralization reforms by (i) efficient devolution of property taxes; (ii) rationalized and 
better-coordinated  approaches  to  key  intergovernmental  transfer  mechanisms;  and  (iii) 
improved public financial management in local governments. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
1.  Output 1: Efficient Devolution of Property Taxes  
11.  The  devolution  of  the  two  main  property  taxes—PBB  and  BPHTB—to  the  local 
governments has commenced in the beginning of 2011, and is expected to be completed by 
2014. The transfer of BPHTB and PBB from central into local taxes is part of a process of 
property taxes decentralization reform, and is not a reform of the property taxes themselves. 
The transfer will (i) improve the accountability of local governments to communities; (ii) increase 
the fiscal autonomy of local finance; and (iii) maintain property records, data and information to 
support the certification of land. The continuation of the existing tax system is crucial, albeit at a 
local level, and there is no need to create a new property tax system. The existing property tax 
system  and  procedures—the  Tax  Object  Information  Management  System  (SISMIOP)  and 
standard operating procedures—function quite well, and their transfer to local governments 
requires  only  moderate  modifications  and  changes.  The  TA  will  assist  the  government  in 
transferring SISMIOP and the standard operating procedures from the national to local level. 
 
12.  For the transition period to be effective, there needs to be proper sequencing and clear 
delegation of responsibilities between the central and local governments to ensure that local 
governments have the ability to manage the two main property taxes. The TA will assist the 
government (i)  develop  sustainable  support  by  designing regular  and  continuous  capacity-
building systems at the central and regional levels; (ii) issue clear guidelines for transferring staff 
from local tax offices to work for the local governments; (iii) provide a monitoring framework for 
local tax offices to ensure smooth implementation of PBB and BPHTB; (iv) develop guidelines 
for PBB implementation that contain the draft regional regulation, and the draft regulation of the 
regent  or  mayor  containing  procedures,  business  processes  and  required  information 
technology;  (v)  develop  pilot  project  areas  to  implement  the  PBB  devolution  strategies, 
especially those related to joint administration, during the transition period; and (vi) design a 
rollout package that will assist the local governments in managing PBB.

4 
 
 
2.  Output  2:  Rationalized  and  Better-Coordinated  Approaches  to  Key 
Intergovernmental Transfer Mechanisms 
 
13.  This output will improve targeting of fiscal transfers and development of performance 
incentives for grant allocations. The TA will review international best practices and current 
development in Indonesia to rationalize the incentive systems and sanctions associated with 
grant  distribution  and  monitoring.  Improved  targeting  of  transfers  by  sector  and  local 
governments  can  multiply  the  impact  of  available  funds  if  applied  to  priority  services  and 
localities. 
 
14.  The TA will seek to make the specific allocation grant (or DAK) more effective as a 
capital grant and to study the enhancement of the Dana Insentif Daerah (performance-based 
fund). The TA will examine how to increase the efficiency of DAK utilization, as the existing DAK 
system does not: (i) provide the local governments with the information needed to execute DAK 
budgets efficiently, (ii) take into account differences in local conditions when determining DAK 
allocation, and (iii) provide for DAK monitoring and evaluation. The TA will look at the long-term 
strategy  for  the  Dana  Insentif  Daerah,  and  in  particular  how  to  integrate  incentives 
arrangements into existing transfer mechanisms, particularly the DAU.  
 
3.  Output 3: Improved Public Financial Management in Local governments. 
 
15.  This  output  will  center  around  capacity  building  of regional  officers  on  PFM.  Local 
governments lack professional PFM officers to manage their finances, with the result that 
financial management system efficiency remains low in many regions. Efforts have been made 
by both MOHA and MOF to implement a financial management information system. However, 
progress has been slow due to (i) overlapping and complicated regulations issued by MOF, 
MOHA,  and  BAPPENAS;  (ii)  the  lack  of  budget  commitment  for  funding  the  needs  of 
decentralized  capacity  building;  (iii)  a  lack  of  incentives  and  accreditation  for  regional 
government finance experts; and (iv) the inability of local officials to access PFM training.  
 
16.  To improve skills and expertise of the local governments and MOF on PFM issues, the 
TA will seek to increase cooperation between MOF and local regional universities, and seek 
innovative way to teach PFM, such as through a distance learning facility. Currently, MOF has 
managed regional finance practices, regional finance training, and finance training for special 
region public management courses in selected regional universities. However, engagement can 
be  further  improved  through  (i)  consolidating  and  simplifying  the  PFM  regulatory  regime 
confronting local governments, (ii) enhanced training in relation to core regulatory requirements, 
(iii) providing incentives for PFM officials to undertake professional study and training, (iv) 
improving the regional finance training and regional finance practices program, (v) expanding 
the  program’s  size  and  outreach,  and  (vi)  promoting  e-learning  courses  and  opportunities 
(linked to professional accreditation) for regional government PFM staff. The TA will also assist 
in implementing financial management information systems in local governments. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to cost $800,000. The TA will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  and  administered  by  ADB.  The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office and housing 
accommodation,  domestic  transportation,  office  space,  communications  facilities  for

5 
 
consultants, and other in-kind contributions. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are 
presented in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.    The executing agency will be the MOF DGFB, which is responsible for overseeing fiscal 
decentralization.  Implementing  agencies  will  include  BAPPENAS,  MOHA  and  local 
governments. The BAPPENAS Directorate of Regional Autonomy is responsible for the DAK 
design. The Directorate General of Regional Financial Management at MOHA bears important 
responsibilities for the implementation of the regional financial management information system 
in  the  local  governments,  and  the  training  for  regional  government  officials  regarding  the 
system. The MOF Directorate of Funding Evaluation and Regional Information Management 
System is responsible for programming and dissemination of the regional financial information 
system  that  enables  local  governments  to  submit  financial  information  to  the  central 
government. The DGFB Directorate for Regional Taxes and Charges is responsible for the 
devolution of the land and building tax to local governments. The TA will start on April 2012 and 
end on April 2014.2 
 
19.  The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). ADB will engage the consultants through 
quality-  and-cost-based  selection  (80:20).  Expressions  of  interest  solicited  from  qualified 
consulting firms will establish the appropriate packaging of the consulting services (one or 
several packages, depending on market testing). A total of 58 (18 international and 40 national) 
person-months of consultant services will be required. The consultants will be tasked with 
assisting the government in the efficient devolution of the property taxes, in developing a 
rationalized and better-coordinated approach to intergovernmental transfers, and building PFM 
capacity among regional government officers. Appendix 3 presents outline terms of reference 
for the consultants. Disbursements under the TA will conform to ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). All procurement will be done in 
accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Any 
equipment to be purchased under the  TA will be transferred to the government upon TA 
completion. All consultant reports and deliverables as required under their terms of reference 
will be delivered to the executing agency at the end of the TA. The consultant team, with the 
help of the executing agency, will be responsible in disseminating reports to the implementing 
agencies. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 to the Government 
of Indonesia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Local 
Government Finance and Governance Reform, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Fiscal Decentralization Specialist and Team Leader (12 person-months) 
 
1.  The fiscal decentralization specialist and team leader will have appropriate postgraduate 
qualifications  in  economics,  finance,  or  public  administration,  and  be  experienced  in  the 
management of medium to large technical assistance (TA) teams, preferably in Indonesia. 
Significant experience is required in policy aspects of fiscal and administrative decentralization, 
including decentralization policy, fiscal policy aspects of decentralization, intergovernmental 
financial  arrangements,  local  tax  and  non-tax  revenue  sources,  and  consistency  of 
decentralization and sector laws. His or her main tasks and outputs include: 
 
(i)  lead, manage, and coordinate all aspects of the TA; 
(ii)  prepare and have approved by the executing agency and Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB)  an  inception  report  focusing  on  management  arrangements  for 
achieving agreed outputs; 
(iii)  prepare and have approved by the executing agency and ADB a final report 
focusing on the outcomes of the TA; 
(iv)  assist in the devolution of the property taxes to local governments, including 
support to policy and administrative reform implementation, and institutional and 
capacity building; 
(v)  review  options  for  enhanced  use  of  incentives  and  sanctions  in  Indonesia’s 
intergovernmental transfer system;  
(vi)  develop  medium-term  approaches  for  managing  the  main  intergovernmental 
transfers  in  the  context  of  developing  a  broader  medium-term  expenditure 
framework for Indonesia; 
(vii)  support  other  consultants  in  the  production  of  all  outputs  and  milestones, 
ensuring timeliness and quality; 
(viii)  provide quality control for all outputs and milestones; 
(ix)  ensure  all  TA  activities  are  complementary  to  activities  of  the  related  (i.e. 
associated) TA and other related development partner activities; 
(x)  have regular discussions and workshops with the Directorate General of Fiscal 
Balance,  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  and  implementing  agencies  on 
implementation progress and various issues, including resolution of bottlenecks; 
(xi)  ensure finalization of all relevant papers and workshops;  
(xii)  administer workshops, trainings, seminars and conferences that are related to 
the TA; 
(xiii)  identify important policy papers for publication, in consultation with the MOF 
Directorate General of Fiscal Balance; and 
(xiv)  provide inputs to and assist the ADB mission leader. 
 
2.  Property Tax Systems Expert (6 person-months, not to be included in firm’s 
request for proposals) 
2.  The property tax systems expert will have appropriate postgraduate qualifications in 
economics, finance, or public administration. Significant experience is required in policy aspects 
of fiscal and administrative decentralization, specifically in the implementation and management 
of decentralized property tax systems. His or her main tasks and outputs include:

(i)  review and streamline the property tax administrative manuals during 2011, to be 
consistent with the local government SISMIOP; 
(ii)  design  and  implement  about  five  pilot  projects  implementing  the  local 
government SISMIOP and refined property tax administrative systems in various 
local government institutional environments; and 
(iii)  assist the team leader and ADB mission leader. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
1.  Decentralization Expert and Deputy Team Leader (15 person-months) 
 
3.  The decentralization expert and deputy team leader will have appropriate postgraduate 
qualifications  in  economics,  finance,  or  public  administration,  and  be  experienced  in  the 
management of medium to large TA teams in Indonesia. Significant experience is required in 
policy  aspects  of  fiscal  and  administrative  decentralization  in  Indonesia,  including 
decentralization  policy,  fiscal  policy  aspects  of  decentralization,  intergovernmental  financial 
arrangements, and local tax and non-tax revenue sources. His or her main tasks and outputs 
include: 
 
(i)  support  the  team  of  international  consultants  in  the  management  and 
coordination of all aspects of the TA; 
(ii)  submit  a  report  documenting  options,  recommendations,  and  a  strategy  for 
performance-based intergovernmental transfer; 
(iii)  assist  MOF  to  strengthen  the  intergovernmental  transfer  monitoring  and 
evaluation system, with a particular focus on the specific allocation fund;  
(iv)  support MOF in preparing the required government regulations and socializing 
the regulations to the regional government; 
(v)  support preparation and approval of all TA administration and technical reports; 
(vi)  support other consultants in producing selected outputs and milestones;  
(vii)  coordinate logistics and manage TA office staff ; and  
(viii)  assist the team leader and ADB mission leader. 
 
2.  Property Tax Expert (10 person-months) 
 
4.  The property tax expert will have appropriate qualifications in economics, public finance, 
or other closely related decentralization disciplines and be experienced in policies and law and 
regulations related to property taxes in Indonesia. Working experience with local governments is 
required.  This  expert  will  work  in  close  tandem  with  and  under  the  supervision  of  the 
international expert on property tax, with the main task being to ensure the local governments 
are able to manage property taxes. The detailed tasks of the consultant include: 
(i)  support MOF in ensuring property tax devolution is carried out smoothly in the 
regions; 
(ii)  assist MOF in developing a framework strategy and guidelines for devolution of 
the land and building tax; 
(iii)  provide support to MOF and local governments on the property tax devolution, 
with monitoring and training; 
(iv)  submit  a  report  documenting  options,  recommendations,  and  a  strategy  for 
further improvement; 
(v)  assist the team leader and ADB mission leader.

Appendix 3       11 
 
 
3.  Capacity-Building Expert (15 person-months) 
 
5.  This  capacity-building  expert  will  have  appropriate  postgraduate  qualifications  in 
economics, finance, or public administration. Significant experience is required in the design 
and reform of public financial management systems. His or her main tasks and outputs include: 
(i)  review and evaluate the quality of training materials and case studies available, 
studying the possible expansion of MOF-supported PFM courses currently run 
through  selected  universities,  and  studying  options  for  introducing  functional 
accreditation schemes for regional and provincial government finance officials; 
(ii)  train and develop teachers leading the program; 
(iii)  further develop curricula, case studies and materials for courses; 
(iv)  support  initial  pilot  development  of  web-based  teaching  approaches  to 
supplement current classroom approaches;  
(v)  support expansion of the number of universities involved in the regional finance 
training and regional finance practices program; and 
(vi)  Assist the team leader and ADB mission leader.
